content:
Please, can someone share a realistic example of a resource using the extensions rendering-markdown or rendering-xhtml?
We need to highlight answers in a QuestionnaireResponse and we think in apply style to these answers (can be xhtml or markdown).
Thanks.

Thanks @Lloyd McKenzie. I copy an example below. Is this an example of the correct use of these extensions? 

{
    "resourceType": "QuestionnaireResponse",
    "id": "52",
    "text": {
        "status": "generated",
        "div": "<div xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml\"> Test markdown and xhtml extensions </div>"
    },
    "status": "in-progress",
    "questionnaire": "Questionnaire/12345",
    "authored": "2021-09-11T19:24:34-03:00",
    "item": [
        {
            "linkId": "1",
            "text": "Example",
            "item": [
                {
                    "linkId": "1.1",
                    "text": "Example Markdown",
                    "_text": {
                        "extension": [
                            {
                                "url": "http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/rendering-markdown",
                                "valueMarkdown": "**Example Markdown** <mark>Highlighted answer</mark>  [Welcome to FHIR](https://www.hl7.org/fhir/)"
                            }
                        ]
                    }
                },
                {
                    "linkId": "1.2",
                    "text": "Example XHTML",
                    "_text": {
                        "extension": [
                            {
                                "url": "http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/rendering-xhtml",
                                "valueString": "<div xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml\"> <p><span style=\"background-color: rgb(247, 218, 100); \"> Highlighted answer XHTML example </span></p> </div>"
                            }
                        ]
                    }
                }
            ]
        }
    ]
}

Regards.
There's no need for the xhtml content to be a div, but otherwise, yes that looks right.
Fran del Río has marked this topic as resolved.

We have the same scenario, needing to render answer responses using HTML. However, I am confused for why the answer is being stored in Questionnaire.item[n].text--is not text suppose to store the text OF the question/group, and the answer stored in answer[].valueX? Should one use the rendering-xhtml extension on answer[].valueString when the answer itself contains html markup?

You can render content as you like. And you can render "allowed answers" with XHTML using an extension. However, the answer itself won't be XHTML. The answer will be a code or an integer or a date or some text typed by the user - and if text, the text typed isn't going to be XHTML or markdown. The most we support right is "text" which is essentially a string where carriage returns and line breaks are supported. If you want to allow an answer to actually be text containing embedded markup, you could submit a change request.
